     A once upon a time in a kingdom far away, there was a young knight named Einon. He was brave and strong but lacked the experience and wisdom to become a great fighter. One day, while training in the castle's courtyard, he encountered an old and wise knight named Sir Bowen.

Sir Bowen was well-known for his knowledge of the Old Code, a set of rules and principles that governed the behavior and conduct of knights in the kingdom. It taught them to be loyal, honorable, and brave in all situations, especially during battles.

Sir Bowen noticed Einon's passion and determination, but he also saw that the young knight needed guidance and discipline. "Careful! Fight with your head don't fight with your heart, boy!" shouted Sir Bowen. He wanted Einon to understand that, while courage and determination were essential, strategic thinking and emotional control were crucial as well.

Einon listened carefully to Sir Bowen's words and began to practice the Old Code in earnest. He trained tirelessly, day and night, learning how to wield his sword and shield with precision and skill. He memorized the Old Code by heart and applied its principles to every aspect of his life.

As Einon grew stronger and more skilled, Sir Bowen continued to teach him the importance of the Old Code. They practiced together, learning from each other'

Given this prompt: The History of Farming Before people started farming they went to the forest to look for plants or fruit they could eat. This meant that people were moving all the time to find food. But about 12000 years ago in the Middle East people began to grow food. These people were the first farmers.
    
    Continue the story and make sure it is readable for A2 learners in the CEFR scale. 
    For your guidance, example books in this level of complexity include A Christmas Carol by Charles Dickens, The Adventures Of Huckleberry Finn by Mark Twain, and The Little Prince by Antoine de Saint-Exupery.

     A Long Time Ago, In The Beginning...

There was a time long ago when people used to move around a lot searching for food. They would go to the forest, looking for plants and fruits to eat. Life was hard and it was very tiring always moving from place to place. But about 12,000 years ago, in a place called the Middle East, things began to change. 

Some people started to grow food instead of just searching for it. They did this by planting seeds in the ground. This made it possible for them to stay in one place and not have to keep moving around. This was a very important change and those people became the very first farmers.

Farmers would plant seeds, take care of the plants, and wait for them to grow. They would then harvest the crops - which means collecting all the ripe plants - and eat the fruits of their labor. This was a lot easier than constantly searching for food. It also meant that there were more people around who were not looking for food, which led to communities forming.

In these communities, people began to specialize in different jobs. Some would become farmers, while others would be in charge of making things like pottery or clothes. There were also people who took care of the sick and the old. Life became more comfortable and easier for these people.

These new ways of living helped the human race to thrive

The winter landscape was beautiful, and once they were on the frozen lake, he could feel the excitement running through him like a current.

The lake had a special significance for Tommy and his father. It was where his dad learned to fish, and now he was teaching Tommy how to do it too. The ice fishing houses were simple but sturdy structures, built of wood and covered in layers of thick ice. Given this prompt: A man heard me and looked round. Then this big man saw me in the corn. He walked to me and I began to shout loudly: ' His foot is going to kill me ! ' The man stopped. For a minute he looked down at me carefully. (We look at a small animal in the same way and think: 'Will it hurt me?
    
    Continue the story and make sure it is readable for A2 learners in the CEFR scale.

     A
      
      There I was, hiding in the tall corn, when suddenly I heard a man nearby. He didn't see me at first, but then he did. He came walking over, and I was scared. My mind started racing, 'This man is so big and strong. If he steps on me, it will hurt so much!'

      I started screaming at the top of my lungs, 'His foot is going to kill me!' The man stopped in his tracks and looked down at me. It was like he was looking at a small animal, unsure if I would harm him or not.

      Then, the big man bent down and slowly raised his foot up. I braced myself, thinking I was about to feel excruciating pain. But to my surprise, the man gently placed his foot beside me and said, 'Don't worry, I won't hurt you.'

      Relieved, I asked him, 'Why are you so kind? What made you change your mind about stepping on me?' The man smiled and replied, 'I saw how much you feared my foot, and I couldn't just hurt you. We all deserve a chance, even the smallest among us.'

      This simple act of kindness from the big man taught me a valuable lesson. We should always be aware of the potential impact our actions might have on others, no matter how small or insignificant

Dear Lynne and Tony,

I'm writing to say thank you for the two nights I stayed in your lovely home. It was good to see you again. Here are the photographs of your children that you asked for. They're good photos, aren't they? I hope you like them. I really love my new camera.

After I took the pictures, I had the opportunity to explore the nearby town. It was very pretty, with lots of nice shops and friendly people. I especially liked the old buildings and the beautiful park in the center of the town.

One of the days, we went to a local museum to learn about the history of the town. The museum had many interesting exhibits about the people who lived there long ago, and I even got to try on some old-fashioned clothing!

In the evening, we had a lovely meal at a nearby restaurant. The food was delicious, and the restaurant had a nice atmosphere. We talked and laughed a lot, and I felt very happy to be with you.

Before I left, you gave me a small gift. It was a beautiful book about the history of the town, which I found very interesting. I will treasure the photos and memories of my time with you, and I hope to visit again soon.

Thank you for making my stay so special and memorable. I miss you both already!

Sincer

   Once upon a time, in the West Country of England, there was a couple called Stephen and Jenny Blackler. They loved working on their farm, Corryvale Farm, where they kept cows, chickens, and many sheep. They were proud of the delicious milk and tasty eggs they produced, but their sheep were the real money-makers.

   Jenny had 50 sheep on their farm. Each sheep had enough wool for 6 sweaters! This was a great asset, especially during the cold winter months. To help their sheep stay cool in the warm summer, Stephen made sure to cut their wool every six months, just enough for six sweaters each time.

   The Blacklers were well-known in the village for their farm, their sheep, and the high-quality products they sold. They often had visitors who came to learn about farming and their famous sheep. It was a happy and fulfilling life on Corryvale Farm for Stephen and Jenny.

Once upon a time, in a beautiful forest near a big river, there lived a group of friendly otters. These otters were very special because most people had never seen them before. They loved living near the river and building their cozy homes from small pieces of wood.

Every night, after the sun went down, the otters would come out of their homes to play and explore the river. They loved swimming in the water, and their thick brown hair kept them warm and cozy while they were in the water. They were also very fast swimmers, able to swim more than 10 kilometers per hour!

One day, a group of adventurous children decided to visit the forest to find out more about these fascinating creatures. As they walked along the riverbank, they saw the otters playing in the water, and they were amazed by how adorable and graceful these animals were.

The children watched as the otters swam around and then climbed onto the bank to rest. They had never seen such a beautiful and unusual sight before. They took out their camera to capture the special moment, and as they did, they felt a sense of joy and wonder.

From that day on, the children returned to the forest to watch the otters and learn from them. They shared their newfound love for these incredible creatures with their friends and family, and soon more and more people started to visit the forest

Nick Barlow is a world traveller and a British actor. He loves his work because it allows him to visit different countries and meet new people. He has been to many places, but there are still a few trips he has not made yet. He dreams of seeing the Northern Lights in Norway, riding an elephant in India, and diving in the Great Barrier Reef in Australia.

Nick's favourite trips include visiting the pyramids in Egypt, exploring the Amazon rainforest in Brazil, and hiking in the mountains of New Zealand. In each country, he meets friendly people who are happy to see him. They show him the best places to visit and give him delicious food to try. Nick loves to learn about different cultures and share his experiences with others.

When he returns home, he has many stories to tell about his adventures. He shows his friends and family photos and videos from his trips, and they all enjoy listening to his stories. Nick also writes a blog about his travels, so people can follow his adventures online. His blog has fans from all over the world, who read about his experiences and dream of going on their own amazing journeys.

Nick is grateful for the opportunities he has had to travel the world and make TV programmes. He knows that his work is not only a job, but also a way to learn and grow as a person. He is excited about the future

The Early Times
Shoes have a long history that dates back thousands of years. In ancient Egypt, they made sandals from papyrus, a plant similar to a reed, for comfort during the hot and dry climate. In ancient Greece, leather shoes were common, and they used various materials to create designs on the shoes. Romans, on the other hand, wore shoes made of leather and animal skins. These shoes were heavy and not very comfortable, but they protected the feet from harsh environments.

In the Middle Ages, shoes became a symbol of social status. The nobility wore extravagant shoes made from fine materials like silk and velvet, while peasants wore simple, practical shoes made from leather. Shoemaking was considered an important craft, and shoe manufacturers played a significant role in local economies. Dear Newport Evening News,

I would like to write a letter to share my wonderful experience with your readers. Last Saturday, I accidentally left my handbag on a bus. I am 72 years old and I live quite far away from the bus stop. I was very worried because inside my handbag, I had my cheque book, address book, and my purse with about £50 and some credit cards.

When I realized what I had done, I felt really worried and I didn't know what to do. I was a long way from home and I didn't know how I was going to get back.

However, something amazing happened that day. A kind-hearted stranger found my handbag and returned it to me. He waited for me at the bus stop until I arrived, and we were both so happy to be reunited with my belongings.

I am grateful for the kindness of this stranger and for the lesson I learned that day. We must always be kind to others and help them when they are in need.

Thank you for letting me share my story with your readers.

Sincerely,

[Place]

"The importance of first impressions cannot be overstated. When you meet someone new, you have only a few minutes to make a positive impact. This is especially true in job interviews, where an employer's opinion of you can be formed within seconds. Here are some tips to help you make a great first impression during an interview:

1. Dress appropriately: Dress in professional attire that is clean, well-fitted, and flattering. Avoid flashy or distracting clothing. If you're unsure about the dress code, err on the side of being too formal rather than too casual.

2. Arrive early: Being punctual shows respect for the interviewer's time. Arrive at least 15 minutes before your scheduled interview time. This will also give you a chance to compose yourself and observe the workplace environment.

3. Maintain eye contact: Eye contact is a crucial part of communication. It demonstrates that you are engaged, confident, and paying attention to the speaker. However, be careful not to stare. Maintaining eye contact for too long can be perceived as aggressive or uncomfortable.

4. Use a firm handshake: A handshake is the first physical contact you'll have with your interviewer. Make sure it's firm, but not too strong. A weak or limp handshake may give the impression that you lack confidence or are not

     Maria was a famous opera singer, and she was performing a beautiful aria. She had a powerful voice that could fill the whole theater. Everybody in the audience was captivated by her performance.

But suddenly, she stopped singing. She looked puzzled, and then her eyes filled with tears. She stood there, motionless, and the audience could feel the sudden change in the atmosphere.

Some people started whispering. What had happened? Why had Maria stopped singing? Maria's sudden reaction had stirred up everyone's curiosity, and the excitement in the theater turned into concern.

Then, they saw Maria walk slowly to the front of the stage. She took a deep breath and, with a trembling voice, she began to sing again. But this time, her voice sounded different. It was full of emotion, and everyone could feel the deep sentiment in her performance.

The audience could not hold back their tears any longer, and they joined Maria in her emotional singing. Raoul, a passionate fan of Maria, couldn't contain himself. He cried out, showing his admiration for the singer and her talent.

Count Philippe, a distinguished figure in the opera world, also jumped up in his box. He was moved by the performance and felt compelled to express his appreciation.

Dolphins have been a popular subject in literature and film for centuries, with their playful and friendly behavior capturing the imagination of people all around the world. However, despite their smiling faces, dolphins are in dire need of our help.

According to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, dolphins are facing numerous threats, such as habitat loss, pollution, and commercial fishing. As a result, their numbers are dwindling, and their future is in jeopardy.

Fishers, in particular, pose a significant threat to dolphins. Dolphins often swim alongside fishing boats, hoping to feed on the same fish. However, many fishers view dolphins as a nuisance, and they often use techniques such as using loud noises or even killing the dolphins to drive them away. These actions not only endanger the dolphins but also disrupt the delicate balance of the marine ecosystem.

Another major issue facing dolphins is pollution. As humans continue to dump waste into our oceans, the water becomes increasingly toxic, affecting the health of dolphins and other marine life. Pollution not only harms dolphins directly but also impacts their food supply, leading to malnutrition and starvation.

At the time, everyone was very curious about how different animals and plants came to be. Many people had their own ideas, but none of them really explained everything. That's when Charles Darwin, a famous scientist, decided to explore this question.

Charles Darwin was born in 1809 in England. He was interested in nature and loved observing the changes happening around him. He noticed that sometimes the offspring of animals were different from their parents. This intrigued Darwin, and he started studying it in detail.

He went on a long journey around the world on a ship named The Beagle. During this journey, he collected many specimens and studied them closely. He observed that animals and plants that were best suited for their environment had the highest chances of survival. This observation led him to develop a groundbreaking theory called the Theory of Evolution.

In 1859, Darwin published a book titled On the Origin of Species. In this book, he shared his thoughts on how life on Earth evolved over a long period of time. He introduced a new idea called natural selection. According to Darwin, natural selection is the process by which the 'fittest' animals or plants are more likely to survive and reproduce.

This was a revolutionary concept, and it had a huge impact on the scientific community. Many people were inspired by Darwin's work, and it changed the way people understood the world

Yours sincerely,
Mary"

As the workplace becomes increasingly complex and competitive, the importance of emotional intelligence cannot be overstated. Emotional intelligence (EI) is the ability to understand, manage, and use our emotions in positive ways to facilitate interpersonal relationships and achieve success. Goleman explores how our emotional skills play a crucial role in our professional lives and the ways we can develop and improve these skills.

Take, for example, Sarah, a talented architect with a keen eye for design. Despite her exceptional technical abilities, she struggled to advance her career due to her lack of emotional intelligence. Sarah often clashed with her colleagues, resulting in a toxic work environment that stifled creativity and collaboration. By learning to listen actively, empathize, and communicate effectively, Sarah was able to improve her emotional intelligence and create a more positive and productive atmosphere at the office.

Similarly, John, a seasoned project manager, found himself struggling to lead his team effectively. Despite his vast experience, he was unable to understand the emotional needs of his team members, causing tension and delays in projects. By focusing on building trust, offering support, and fostering open communication, John developed his emotional intelligence and became a more successful leader.

In ancient times, people used to chew on the sap of trees for various reasons. This sticky substance, called gum, provided them with a temporary feeling of fullness in their stomachs and helped with bad breath. However, the gum back then was nothing like the chewing gum we know and love today.

Over time, the process of creating chewing gum improved. In 1871, a man named Thomas Adams invented the first commercial chewing gum. He made it using the sap from the chicle tree.      Peter Preston worked in his home office on a Sunday afternoon. He was a newspaper editor, and he was worried about the future of his profession. He knew that more and more people were reading news online, and fewer were buying physical newspapers.

"The end of print may take some time," he thought. "But it's inevitable. Change is coming, and we have to adapt."

As the years passed, Peter noticed that many newspapers had already made the transition to the online world. Some were doing well, while others struggled. He wondered if his own newspaper could survive the change.

One day, Peter received an email from a young tech entrepreneur named Lucy. She had read some of his articles online and wanted to discuss the future of newspapers with him. Curious, Peter agreed to meet her.

When they met, Lucy shared her vision for a new kind of newspaper that would combine the best of print and online formats. "Why can't we have a newspaper that you can hold in your hands but also access online?" she asked. "That way, we can reach more readers and keep the tradition of journalism alive."

Peter listened carefully as Lucy explained her ideas. He could see the potential in her plan. "We should definitely explore this option," he said. "It could be the solution we need to survive in the digital age."

Together, Peter and Lucy began working on their new newspaper.

     B. Enter a store and you might find yourself leaving with more than what you planned to buy. There are many techniques that retailers use to make shoppers part with their hard-earned money. One of them is called the image of freshness.

Supermarkets, for example, focus on providing fresh produce on their shelves because they know from their market research that shoppers place a high value on freshness. To enhance the perception of freshness, stores use techniques like having regular replenishment of stock, bright lighting, and even playing nature sounds over the PA system. The idea is to make the shopping experience feel lively and natural, which in turn encourages consumers to buy more of the products they see as fresh and good for them.

In addition to the image of freshness, retailers also employ other tactics to persuade you to spend more. One such strategy is the use of endcaps and displays that highlight certain items and encourage impulse purchases.   Isabella, better known as Isabel, was a 31-year-old art student from a small town. She spent most of her time reading historical romances. Isabel knew what she wanted in a man: Mr Right. She believed she had the qualities to find him, but she was also concerned about one thing - her knobbly knees. 

One sunny Saturday morning, Isabel decided to go to the local park. As she was walking, she noticed a group of people practicing tai chi. The sight of the peaceful and balanced movements caught her attention. Curiosity piqued, she decided to join them.

It was not long before she was among the group, trying her best to imitate the slow and gentle movements. She soon found herself facing a tall, dark-haired man. As they both tried to step into the same position, they accidentally bumped into each other.

"Ouch!" Isabel said, rubbing her knees where she had knocked them against each other. The man looked up, and Isabel was surprised to see the most beautiful smile on his face. 

"I'm so sorry, I didn't mean to bump into you. Are you okay?" he asked, a hint of concern in his voice. 

"Yes, I'm fine. It's just my knobbly knees," Isabel replied, laughing.

The man laughed

There are a few theories which scientists have proposed to explain the necessity of sleep, but they are not in complete agreement yet.

The first theory suggests that sleep is important for memory consolidation. The human brain needs time to process and store information, and sleep is the ideal opportunity for this. During sleep, the brain forms connections between neurons which are essential for learning and memory.

The second theory proposes that sleep is crucial for the body's physical growth and repair. During sleep, our body goes through a period of rest and recovery. This is when our body can focus on repairing damaged tissues, building new muscles, and maintaining our overall health.

The third theory is that sleep is essential for our survival instinct. Sleep allows us to conserve energy so that we can be more alert and active during the day. It is believed that our ancestors who slept well were more likely to survive, as they were better equipped to face challenges and predators.

In conclusion, while scientists may not have reached a definitive answer yet, the evidence suggests that sleep plays a crucial role in both our physical and mental well-being. It remains an important area of research for the future, as understanding the true function of sleep could lead to new treatments and therapies for a range of health conditions.

So, the next time you feel guilty about hitting the snooze button, remember that sleep is a vital part of being human,

Fashion is a term that is often associated with the modern era, particularly the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Many people believe that fashion is solely dependent on capitalism for its development. However, historians of fashion argue that fashion, in terms of style and design, has been around for a very long time. They commonly point to the rise of the market and mercantile trade in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries as the starting point of this history.

During the Middle Ages, clothing was mainly handmade by individuals or small groups. It was often made for specific purposes such as religious ceremonies or special occasions. People were more concerned with functionality and practicality rather than style or design. However, as society evolved and trade began to flourish, people started to pay more attention to their appearance.

The sixteenth and seventeenth centuries marked a turning point in the history of fashion. As trade expanded, different cultures and regions began to exchange ideas, goods, and influences. This led to a greater diversity of clothing styles and designs. People started to wear clothes that were not only functional but also fashionable.

Oral history has become very popular for historians who want to understand the past. They like to talk to people who lived through important events. However, they must be careful when using oral history because it is not always completely accurate.

When a historian interviews someone, both the historian and the person being interviewed are affected by each other. This means that their conversation can be influenced by their beliefs, feelings, and experiences.

For example, a historian might be interviewing someone about a famous event. The person being interviewed may want to present their story in a certain way, so they might remember the event differently than it really happened. This can make it difficult for the historian to get an accurate picture of the past.

On the other hand, oral history can be a useful tool for understanding the past, especially when there are not many written records available. Oral history can help historians learn about the emotions and motivations of the people who lived through the events they are studying.

To make sure that oral history is as accurate as possible, historians need to be careful when choosing who to interview. They should try to find people who were actually present during the events they are studying. They should also ask a variety of questions to get different perspectives on the same event.

  Charles Darwin, one of the most famous scientists in history, studied many aspects of the natural world and came to the conclusion that there was no particular reason why humans should cry. This idea has been challenged and revised over the years and many experts today believe that there is indeed a good reason for our tears.

   This idea was first introduced to the world back in the 1950s, but has become increasingly more accepted and understood since then. Bowlby highlighted how tears, particularly in childhood, are a way for a child to express that they are helpless, they are vulnerable and they need their mother's care and protection.

The English breakfast, which is a meal often consisting of eggs, bacon, sausages, beans, tomatoes, mushrooms, and sometimes even black pudding, has changed dramatically over the centuries.

In the Middle Ages, people in England would eat a modest breakfast, if they ate one at all. It usually consisted of bread and cheese, with the possibility of some porridge on special occasions. However, during this time, breakfast wasn't considered a vital part of the day like it is today.

The importance of breakfast didn't become widely known until the late 18th and early 19th centuries when many famous doctors and health experts started to preach about the benefits of eating a substantial meal in the morning. This helped to popularise the idea of the English breakfast, which at the time was still very rare.

One of the first people to take advantage of this new trend was John Montagu, the 4th Earl of Sandwich. Legend has it that he created the sandwich as we know it today, by wrapping meat between two pieces of bread. This made it easy for him to eat while continuing his work. In this way, he inadvertently introduced one of the most iconic components of the English breakfast to the world.
